Award.AwardTitle: FASEB 2017 Conference on Genetic Recombination and Genome Rearrangements; July 16-21, 2017, Steamboat Springs, Colorado

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The FASEB Research Conference on Genetic Recombination and Chromosome Rearrangements will be held at Steamboat Springs, Colorado on July 16-21, 2017. This is the seventeenth in a series of bi-annual conferences devoted to promoting cross-disciplinary discussion at the leading edge of research on DNA recombination. The 2017 meeting features an increased emphasis on quantitative approaches that bring new understanding to various areas comprising genetic recombination; for example, high-throughput sequencing and copy number variation analysis to study genome rearrangements globally within organisms and across populations; mass spectrometry-based methods that globally assess protein and DNA marks; single molecule approaches to recombination biochemistry. This meeting also features research that is needed to understand and exploit emerging genome engineering technologies such as CRISPR-Cas9.

The goal of this conference is to bring together researchers from around the world who work in recombination and the related field of genomic rearrangements, and to give young and starting investigators the opportunity to present and discuss their work. The format of the meeting involves talks from invited speakers who are leaders in the field, speakers chosen from submitted abstracts, and poster sessions. For 2017, there are 47 invited speakers, 36% of whom are women (including the keynote speaker) and 30% of whom are new to the conference. The number of program slots to be filled from submitted abstracts has been increased significantly (to 24%) with the goal of increasing participation opportunities and visibility for underrepresented groups and young scientists.

The requested funds will be used for fellowships to help defray travel and meeting costs for 10 junior scientists. The organizers will prioritize support for underrepresented groups and preferentially graduate students and post-doctoral fellows with NSF funds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology (FASEB) is a non-profit federation of scientific societies covering life sciences research. Every year, FASEB sponsors science research conferences (SRCs) that allow researchers working in particular fields to meet in an intensive, interactive setting to explore new research areas. These conferences are supported from a variety of sources: conference fees and grants from industry, private foundations and federal government. In 2017, a FASEB SRC, Genetic Recombination and Genome Rearrangements, was held to promote interaction among our scientists.

 

Genetic recombination plays a key role in molding genome structure and maintaining genome integrity in all organisms. Recombination, both homologous and non-homologous, repairs DNA damage by mechanisms that can be mutagenic and constitute an important source of genetic alterations. Recombination is essential for fertility and reproductive success. Substantial progress has been made in understanding recombination, but much remains to be learned regarding the underlying mechanisms, the regulation, and the consequences of this fundamental biological process. The conference is devoted to promoting progress in these areas.

 

The conference included over 60 oral presentations of research results and more than 70 posters, which were usually presented by graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, or junior faculty. This SRC has a special emphasis on young researchers at early stages in their scientific careers. Funding by a conference grant from the National Science Foundation provided support for several young scientists who might not otherwise have been able to attend because of financial constraints.
